abstract.p: Cynthia S Pader letter on April 30 travel article on foreign shopping trips describes how she selects plates to add to her collection (S)

block.p: To the Editor: ''I Shop and the World Is a Better Place'' (April 30) reminded me of shopping for the plate collection that adorns my dining room walls.

Yes, I have certain criteria for plate purchases. The plate cannot be a souvenir with the place of origin scrawled across it. It has to be ''indigenous'' -- made in the country where I am -- with a motif or pattern characteristic of that country.
To the Editor: ''I Shop and the World Is a Better Place'' (April 30) reminded me of shopping for the plate collection that adorns my dining room walls.

Yes, I have certain criteria for plate purchases. The plate cannot be a souvenir with the place of origin scrawled across it. It has to be ''indigenous'' -- made in the country where I am -- with a motif or pattern characteristic of that country.

It is always hard to refrain from being so obsessed with finding a plate that I miss the foreign environment for which I came. I have a friend who uses the same criteria for finding posters. When I visited her in California last year she said, ''Here's where I've been,'' and threw open her garage, which was completely papered with self-explanatory posters of her travels, which she considers therapeutic reminders of good times.
